comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: ''And poet lost to potato-fields, Remembering the lime and copper smell Of the spraying barrels he is not lost Or till blossomed stalks cannot weave a spell.'' Patrick Kavanagh (1905-1969), Irish poet, novelist. Spraying the Potatoes (l. 29-32). . . Norton Anthology of Poetry, The. Alexander W. Allison and others, eds. (3d ed., 1983) W. W. Norton & Company. www.poemhunter.com/patrick-kavanagh/quotations/page-4/

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
I love the way the buttercups (Common Name:Creeping Buttercup,
Scientific Name:Ranunculus repens
Irish Name:Fearbán (reatha)
have colour popped around the poet, as if in homage to the great man and his geansaí!
While you could not but like his poetry I always considered him a boor and a bit of a bully, which he probably was but he sure could write!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Marigolds is an unlikely choice, I've done some searching and the two that most resemble them are "Butterworth" and "Hawkweed" but they are both relatively rare and not often seen in these parts?  Apart from that I love the way the colour is so much brighter and distinct compared to the rest of the shot which looks slightly faded!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Marigolds are a wonder-drug of the companion plant world, invoking the saying "plant them everywhere in your garden". French marigolds produce a pesticidal chemical from their roots, so strong it lasts years after they are gone. Mexican marigolds do the same, but are so strong they will inhibit the growth of some more tender herbs. Certain Varieties of marigolds (Tagetes) can help manage eelworms (Root-knot nematode) when planted the year before [1]. Tagetes has also been found effective against perennial weeds such as Ranunculus ficaria (Celandine), Aegopodium podagraria (Ground elder), Glechoma hederacea (Ground ivy), Agropyron repens (Couch grass), Convolvulus arvensis (Field bindweed), Equisetum arvense (Field/Common Horsetail) and other 'starchy' weeds.
